reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s moral-uncertainty section (intertheoretic normalization) and claims the “fussiness dominates” upshot is largely an artifact of scaling choices. This is only moderately central: the main thrust of “no easy eutopia” is supported independently by the fragility/product-of-factors story and the taxonomy of bounded/unbounded value functions; even if the moral-uncertainty punchline weakened, much of the paper would stand. The objection has some force against any claim that, under moral uncertainty, unbounded/linear (fussy) views should loom large; it correctly notes that different plausible normalization rules can reverse recommendations and suggests robustness-style decision rules as an alternative. However, it doesn’t engage the paper’s own acknowledgments/nuance (it already flags thorniness and avoids strong conclusions), and it doesn’t show that reasonable comparison principles would systematically favor easygoingness—only that the argument becomes conditional. Relevance is moderate-to-high because it bears on an important, decision-relevant open issue for Forethought (how to act under moral uncertainty and whether that pushes toward fussy conclusions), even if it’s not the dominant Tier 3 agenda item. Overall, it modestly weakens one strand rather than seriously threatening the overall position.
title: "Normalization choices undermine moral uncertainty aggregation"
